stem: The nurse reviews the clinical data from 0800 to 1100. Which finding most clearly indicates a therapeutic response to the interventions?

options.text: T wave amplitude increasing from 6mm to 8mm.
QRS interval widening from 0.10 seconds to 0.12 seconds.
Serum potassium level decreasing from 6.8 mEq/L to 5.2 mEq/L.
Heart rate decreasing from 88 bpm to 72 bpm with peaked T waves.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 0745: SBAR Report from night shift. Patient with CKD admitted for hyperkalemia. Complains of muscle weakness. ECG shows peaked T waves. Kayexalate and insulin/dextrose ordered.0800: Kayexalate administered per rectum. Insulin 10 units IV and D50W IV given. Patient reports continued weakness.0930: Patient reports slight improvement in muscle strength. Repeat ECG shows tall T waves, less peaked.1100: Patient states feeling much better, muscle weakness improved. ECG shows T waves less prominent.

tabs.title: Provider Orders
tabs.content:
• Kayexalate 30 grams PR q6h PRN for K+ > 5.5 mEq/L
  • Insulin Regular 10 units IV stat, followed by D50W IV stat
  • Monitor ECG continuously
  • Repeat serum potassium q2h

rationale.correctRationale: A decreasing serum potassium level from 6.8 mEq/L at 0800 to 5.2 mEq/L at 1100 most clearly indicates a therapeutic response to the interventions (Kayexalate and insulin/dextrose). The goal of treatment is to reduce the potassium level to a safer range.

incorrectRationales.option_1: Increasing T wave amplitude indicates worsening hyperkalemia, not a therapeutic response. T wave changes are a key ECG manifestation of hyperkalemia.
incorrectRationales.option_2: Widening QRS interval also suggests worsening hyperkalemia and potential cardiac conduction abnormalities. This is an adverse sign.
incorrectRationales.option_4: While a decreasing heart rate can be a positive sign in some contexts, the presence of peaked T waves indicates that hyperkalemia is still affecting the heart, negating the potential benefit of the heart rate change. The potassium level itself needs to decrease for a true therapeutic response.

rationale.correct: Clinical rationale pending deep clinical alignment.

clinicalPearls: Monitor serial potassium levels, ECG changes, and muscle strength during hyperkalemia treatment. Be alert for signs of hypokalemia after treatment.
questionTrap: Students may focus on ECG changes without considering the potassium level, which is the most direct indicator of treatment success. They also may not recognize the trend of the potassium level over time.
